cleaned_text: treatment [Jump - The process or manner of [treating](/wiki/treat)someone or something. - He still has nightmares resulting from the abusive treatment he received from his captors. [Medical](/wiki/medical)care for an [illness](/wiki/illness)or [injury](/wiki/injury). - A treatment or cure is applied after a medical problem has already started. - Cancer survivors who got radiation treatments as children have nearly twice the risk of developing diabetes as adults. - The change is due largely to the increased availability of antiretroviral treatment. - - The use of a [substance](/wiki/substance)or [process](/wiki/process)to [preserve](/wiki/preserve)or give particular properties to something. - ( [countable](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#countable)) A [treatise](/wiki/treatise); a [formal](/wiki/formal)written description or characterization of a subject. - 1992, Rudolf M[athias] Schuster, The Hepaticae and Anthocerotae of North America: East of the Hundredth Meridian, volume V, New York, N.Y.: [Columbia University Press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbia_University_Press), [ISBN](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-914868-20-0), page vii: - Firstly, I continue to base most species treatments on personally collected material, rather than on herbarium plants. - ( [countable](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#countable), [film](/wiki/film#Noun)) A brief, third-person, process or manner of treating | | medical care for an illness or injury | | preserving or giving particular properties | | - The translations below need to be checked and inserted above into the appropriate translation tables.
